description: The erasure channel models the complete loss of a qubit, where the qubit transitions to a detectable non-computational state |e⟩. Unlike other noise channels, the location of an erasure error is known (heralded) because the qubit is flagged as lost, making erasure errors significantly easier to correct than general Pauli errors.

Erasure is the dominant error mechanism in photonic quantum computing (photon loss) and is increasingly relevant in neutral atom arrays where atoms can be lost from optical traps. Recent work has shown that certain superconducting qubit architectures can be engineered to convert leakage into detectable erasure, dramatically improving error correction thresholds.

The erasure threshold for quantum error correction is approximately 50% per qubit, compared to roughly 11% for depolarizing noise, making erasure-dominated systems attractive for fault-tolerant quantum computing.
physical_examples: Photon loss in linear optical quantum computing
Atom loss from optical traps in neutral atom arrays
Engineered erasure qubits in superconducting systems (dual-rail transmons)
Fiber transmission loss in quantum communication
qem_considerations: Post-selection on non-erased qubits is the simplest mitigation strategy
QED codes can efficiently detect and discard erased qubits
Symmetry verification can flag missing qubits via conserved quantity violations
Erasure is easier to handle than general noise: known location reduces overhead for both QEM and QEC
